1067662893804449792.text: @dwbush It also doesn’t scale. If I’m a maintainer of a small OSS package, there might be *occasional* requests for maintenance, but not enough to earn a full time income. So, if I want to earn a living wage, I have to maintain a *fleet* of packages.

1067662643186429952.text: @dwbush It doesn’t work because of misaligned incentives. The better you are at your job (i.e., less bugs), the less revenue you earn. If you have an area of code that is prone to bugs, and you refactor it to be better, your revenue stream dries up entirely.

1067659731911696385.text: OSS devs need to have LLCs for themselves and day-job contracts that respect that. Corps need to understand the OSS ROI and throw a (small N) few grand at a particular bug/feature. Yes, there might be an arbitrage here.
